column4: Eh, alright. I suppose I'll wait around some more befor etaking the plunge... Maybe someone's heard of it.
A virtual serial port for Linux.
Now this is embarrassing... What is /dev/tty*?
Oh, and, I don't seem to actually have a /dev/tty.
/dev/tty* are all your serial devices ... you use them for e.g. console login
So if I write to, say, /dev/tty1, I'll write to a vrtual port? Where does the data go?
? You just said you were writing to the virtual port => data goes to virtual port ... if noone is listening, then data will be 'lost'
We're writing software for hardware connected to a pc through an RS-232. We used to do it in delphi but I want to try Java...  have to get a hang of how it works first though.
Basically I need a java executable that, when run on a windows box with an RS 232, will be able to write to and read from the port.
I'd suggest to use the real port (usually /dev/ttyS0)
Didn't you say that is the physical port?
not sure how java accesses it ... perhaps you should check #java instead? (probably there are already ways to do it)
I was just thinking of that... Thanks for the tip, I'll go check there.
yes, exactly ... why 'mess' with virtual ports when you can test it as easily with physical ports?
